I'm not sure I like the idea of deducting xp for nodes which are not deleted. First, there is the possibility of abuse--for example, someone could bait by posting junk and then change it once it was considered. Next, I think it has the potential to inhibit the proper functioning of consideration as people choose not to consider due to a fear of losing xp. We already have a situation where the perceived negative aspect of downvoting leads people to consider rather than downvote (or so it often seems, when you see nodes with multiple delete votes and a positive reputation). There's also the question of whether we should decide what grounds for deletion are, or whether perlmonks as a whole should decide that.

The other suggestions, like sorting out edit from delete, I'm in favour of. Could we make use of [id://6345|'editor requests'] to handle the edit consideration by giving it the same kind of interface as nodes to consider? Right now I'm not sure what purpose it is serving.

[Petruchio] Thu Jul 12 01:49:29 EDT 2001

Without doubt, if we assume all node reaping powers, we are taking power away from the monks at large. This is not to say it's a bad idea, but I think it best we speak of it frankly. It may be the best choice for our community, but we are again centralizing the power structure. We are also increasing the workload for the [editors].

I think several things are worth considering before we choose to do this.

First off, it's hard to have reasonable expectations about the consideration process, when no guidelines exist. We're having the same troubles with the [Nodes to Consider|NTC] that we're having with the conduct of individual [editors]; people have been set a task, without instructions or goal, and they're getting it wrong. It would be interesting to see how use changed if such things were made explicit.

I think as well that we should ponder the mechanism we've got in light of our objectives. For instance, there are two distinct cases handled by the consideration process: requests for deletion, and requests for editorial intervention of one sort or another. The consideration mechanism itself makes no distinction between these cases.

Also, we can distinguish two cases which have much different implications: sometimes a person considers his own node, and sometimes a person considers someone else's node. It takes much less judgement to reckon whether a node should be reaped or moved when the request comes from the author. The consideration mechanism does supply the name of the considerer, which makes things easer for the voter; there is still no actual difference in the way these cases are handled, though.

The quickest, easiest remedy I can think of would be to publish criteria for considering a node, and add an appropriate link to the consideration nodelet. Then publish criteria for voting on considered nodes, display either the criteria or a link to the criteria on the [Nodes to Consider|NTC] page. The process for determining these criteria is another matter.

I think a technological solution would actually serve better.

I can see little reason to keep nodes considered for deletion and those considered for editing in the same list; likewise, I think that it is on the whole a drawback that people may vote 'delete' for nodes considered for editing, and vice-versa.

Lower standards for action would seem reasonable when a node is considered by its author.

And I also think that more accountability for those who choose to participate would be a good thing. Having the considerer's name made public is a good thing; I would consider making him directly liable, too. As the ancient Athenians fined someone who brought suit against another and lost, I think that someone who considers a node for deletion should lose XP if many people vote to 'keep'. The voting system, with it's $NORM value, might serve as a model for this. If this deters people from participating... good.

Letting the 'public' mostly run the consideration process is, if only from a pragmatic, Lazy standpoint, a Good Thing... assuming it actually worked. I would prefer to see the process centralized to seeing it continue as it has been; but perhaps we can strike a balance which works instead.

[tye] 2001-07-11
Regarding [id://95476] which was considered with "(agoth) nonsense, plus who on earth put this on the front page???". This is the type of thing I /msg the considerer about asking what they wanted done. This usually evokes some response about the node being "questionable" and wanting everyone to figure out what to do about it.

I think that this actually results in nodes being reaped when the person considering it wasn't really convinced that it should be deleted: The considerer thinks "well, people will vote on it so I don't really have to think about whether it should really be deleted or not" and voters think "well, it has been considered so I'll just 'do my part' and help it get 'cleaned up'" and also don't bother to think about it too much (other than, "yeah, it is kinda ugly, isn't it?").

Retiring the NodeReaper will make this a much less serious problem. I think we should announce this such that people realize that we aren't taking away their power, we are just replacing an automatic (and flawed) "decision" on their request with a decision by a qualified human so that obvious stuff will probably get reaped faster and easier while the tough decisions will be weighed more slowly and carefully.

Oh, and I put that node on the front page because it had been around for a while with no answer. The error message seemed rather specific so I was hoping someone would know rather precisely what that message meant and some broader exposure for it would help.

Anyway, I'll /msg this to agoth and eventually unconsider it.

Feel free to express your disagreement (or agreement) with me on any of this, of course. (:

Before saying anything else, I'd like to thank [neshura] for the most stimulating exchange I've had in awhile.

I share her view that the present situation is not tenable. It is certainly not scalable. I do not customarily work as root on my own box, and I use strict while working indepentantly on my own code; the idea of a system with 22 sorta-root users running around without even solid policies in place is indeed spooky.

There are two difficulties with technological solutions. First, they take time and effort to implement. Second, decisions -- and possibly difficult ones -- must be made as to what constraints should be put in place. If a Developers group is formed, the former problem will be much less serious; the latter perhaps more serious.

In the nearer term, I think we need to improve our current cultural solution. There is some very general understanding of proper conduct; it is evidently not sufficient. I believe we need real policies.

I propose that we collectively create the Lex Emendatori... the Code of the Editors. Let's propose some tenets, debate them, and form a Code out of those which seem good. This would give an editor at least some objective standards to guide his actions, and everyone else a rational measure by which to judge him.

The forum for this is a little more difficult. I would suggest that the [editors] use a wiki to create a rough draft, and then post the draft for public [Perl Monks Discussion|Discussion]. Then create a final draft, taking into account the opinions aired, and adopt it.

I see two reasonable objections to this approach (assuming, for the moment, that people don't object to the whole idea). First, that such a method is not egalitarian enough. I tend to think that the business of composing would go more easily with a smaller group in a flexible medium, and that the key thing would be to take the public debate strongly into account. Second, that this is simply too much todo over what will probably be a very short document. This may be. But if it works well, the approach might serve well for other problems... such as what sorts of technological changes we'd like see made to the site.

As a practical matter as well, I would like for us to collect and distill our knowledge of editorial powers and limitations, along with some explanations as to what different things mean. Forming such a document, however, would seem an appropriate editors-only matter.

*whew* Sorry for the long-winded blather. I'm not only argumentative, I talk too much... but then you knew that before you invited me here. :-) It may be that much of this should be taking place in [Perl Monks Discussion|Discussion], but I wanted to say it here first, to test the waters.

If you come across a bear in the wilderness, curl up into a ball, keeping all your limbs tucked in and lay very, very still. Continue to do this for a long time, then continue to do it longer. The bear will lose interest if you are not moving, but may still be in the area, so it is imperative that you remain still long after you think it has left.

Um...so anyway...I vote to always keep "politically controversial" nodes (i.e. those that may be cause large organizations to stand up and take notice), but edit nodes that are simply offensive (be it erotic ASCII art, ugly font tags, personal attacks, porn, spam, etc.) If we roll over right away for controversial nodes, then thugs like the MPAA have already won through sheer intimidation. I feel that many internet sites should (and must) be heavily moderated to maintain a decent signal/noise ratio and keep troublemakers out, but fear of repercussion should never be a factor, only how the content will be received by the community that is reading it.

By all means, take umbrage, [Petruchio|honored warrior-editor]. No battle is ever won by rolling over and playing dead, unless you are out in the wilderness and you encounter a bear, maybe. I'll argue my hardest ("DO X BECAUSE") because this isn't tea time with the Queen Mother, this is putting together checks and balances in a community that, among other things, is trying to reengineer democracy in a new medium. Certainly one could scoff that it is only a web site and there are more important things in the world to do, which there are, and one is free to go do them, in most locales.

It is only by virtue of the fact that I am part of the [editors] that I can pretend (as pretense it necessarily is) to hold any editor accountable for actions taken with the aid of an astonishing level of power -- certainly no non-editor can even pretend. You as editors can't be unaware that you could change the wording of every [Anonymous Monk] post if that were your whim. You could systematically change the posts of everyone who ever disagreed with you; as long as you are careful to change only the older posts, you might never get caught. You could change [vroom]'s posts. You require no warrant from a judge, no unified editor opinion, no permission from the poster.

That means I have to trust [vroom]'s trust in each of you. Maybe you can understand that I don't readily cleave to the concept, given that I barely trust myself with the Omnipotent Red Pen of Justice and Good Taste. The job of the [editors] is whatever the [editors] want it to be; the charter was something the original editors worked out about "fix formatting but no content except sometimes delete it", I'm not really sure exactly. The charter, which is only in our heads, is painfully unresistant to demagoguery. At this very moment I'm waging a campaign of words to convince all of you to delete less, edit less, and support the implementation of technological checks and balances. I'll fight hard for it. I think I fight fairly most of the time -- sometimes I screw up and if I have personally hurt anyone's feelings, I want to hear about it.

I'm not going to go into what I think the checks and balances should be (/msg me for that), because I still have to convince you that there is a gross imbalance of power. We're the police, we're also the judges, and our rule can't be overturned except by one [vroom|overworked dude] who can't possibly keep up with all our editorial maneuvers. Maybe we should wait until there is some unconscionable abuse of power, but maybe by that time we'll be so apathetic that we'll just shrug. Or maybe we won't consider it abuse, because we've been on a slippery slope and have lost track of the big picture. Do you think the community should trust us so blindly?
